characters.name: <geographical distribution>
data: <Species of \i{}Anischia\i0{} are known from the Neotropical region, New Guinea, New Caledonia and Australia.>
<Artematopodines are distributed throughout most of the New World, from northern North America to Brazil and are also known from southern Europe, eastern Siberia and Japan.>
<The genus \i{}Electribius\i0{} is known from southern Mexico and Guatemala, and also occurs in the Oligocene of northern Europe (Baltic amber).>
<The genus \i{}Brachypsectra\i0{} occurs in the arid parts of southwestern North America, southern India, Malaysia and northern Australia.>
<Agriline Buprestidae are widely distributed in all major regions of the world, but they do not occur in New Zealand.>

<Aphanisticini are native to the Old world. \i{}Aphanisticus\i0{} occurs throughout the Palaearctic, Afrotropical and Oriental regions and in New Guinea and northern Australia; however \i{}A. cochinchinae seminulum Obenberger has been introduced into Hawaii and Texas (Wellso 1995). \i{}Anthaxomorphus\i0{} is known from Africa, Asia, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and northern Australia. \i{}Endelus\i0{} extends throughout the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions, from Japan and India to the East Indies, and in New Guinea and northern Australia.>
<The Brachyini occur throughout the New World from Canada to Argentina, but a species of \i{}Taphrocerus\i0{} has been described from southern Africa (Bellamy and Hespenheide 1988).>
<Cylindromorphine Buprestidae occur throughout most of the Old World, from western Europe to Japan and China and south to southern Africa, Madagascar, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<Species of \i{}Zitella\i0{} occur in central and southern Africa.>
<The genera \i{}Cylindromorphoides\i0{} and \i{}Eurynodes\i0{} both occur in Brazil.>
<The genus \i{}Galbella\i0{} occurs from Southeast Asia and India to Asia Minor, the Mediterranean region, Africa and Madagascar.>
<The genus \i{}Germarica\i0{} occurs only in Australia.>

<The genus \i{}Pachyschelus\i0{} occurs throughout the New World from Canada to Argentina, and in Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia and the East Indies. \i{}Hylaeogena\i0{} occurs in tropical America, from Mexico to Argentina.>

<The genera \i{}Trachys\i0{} and \i{}Habroloma\i0{} occur throughout the Palaearctic, Afrotropical and Oriental regions, and the latter extends into New Guinea and Australia. \i{}Neotrachys\i0{} occurs in tropical America, from Guatemala to Brazil and Bolivia.>
<The subfamily Buprestinae occurs in all major regions of the world.>
<\i{}Acmaeoderella\i0{} (\i{}Kocheridia\i0{}) \i{}trifoveolata\i0{} (Lucas) occurs in North Africa and Asia Minor.>
<\i{}Castiarina antia\i0{} Barker occurs in Western Australia.>
<\i{}Castiarina variegata\i0{} (Blackburn) (= \i{}Hypostigmodera\i0{}) occurs in New South Wales and Queensland.>
<The genus \i{}Julodimorpha\i0{} is restricted to the more arid parts of southern Australia from Western Australi to western Victoria and New South Wales.>

<Mastogeniine Buprestidae occur throughout the New World from the eastern and southwestern United States to Chile, in the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions through the East Indies and New Guinea to Fiji and Australia, and in Asia Minor, South Africa and Madagascar.>
<The genera \i{}Mendizabalia\i0{} and \i{}Philandia\i0{} occur in the Valdivian region of Chile.>
<The genus \i{}Paratrachys\i0{} occurs from Japan to India, Southeast Asia, the East Indies, New Guinea and Australia.>
<Species of \i{}Thrincopyge\i0{} occur from the southwestern United States (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) to south-central Mexico.>

<The genus \i{}Xenorhipis\i0{} occurs in eastern North America and the Bahamas, \i{}Hesperorhipis\i0{} and \i{}Trichinorhipis\i0{} are known from California and Arizona, \i{}Isophaenus\i0{} occurs in Mexico and Cuba, and \i{}Australorhipis\i0{} occurs in the more arid parts of southern Australia.>
<\i{}Xyroscelis\i0{} is an Australian genus, with one species occurring in New South Wales and another in Western Australia.>

<The genus \i{}Sternocera\i0{} occurs in Southeast Asia, India and Sri Lanka, the southern part of the Arabian Peninsula, and most of sub-Saharan Africa (but not the Cape region). \i{}Julodis\i0{} occurs from southern Europe, Central Asia and Asia Minor to North Africa, with an isolated group in southern Africa. \i{}Amblysterna\i0{} and \i{}Neojulodis\i0{} occur in eastern and southern Africa, \i{}Julodella\i0{} occurs in southwestern Africa, Asia Minor and Central Asia, and \i{}Aaata\i0{} is known only from southern Iran and Pakistan.>

<The Schizopodinae are known from the southwestern part of North America. \i{}Schizopus\i0{} species occur in the arid parts of southern Nevada, southwestern Arizona, southern and eastern California and northern Baja Califoria; \i{}Dystaxia\i0{} are widely distributed in California and northern Baja California; and \i{}Glyptoscelimorpha\i0{} are restricted to southern California.>
<The genus \i{}Amphicyrta\i0{} occurs in western North America, from central California to southern Oregon.>
<Byrrhines occur in the cooler, temperate parts of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, and do not occur in tropical regions.>

<Syncalyptine Byrrhidae occur in most parts of the world, but they appear to be more common in the North and South Temperate regions. The genus \i{}Chaetophora\i0{} is widespread in the Northern Hemisphere, but also occurs in the Neotropical and Afrotropical regions. \i{}Curimopsis\i0{} is distributed throughout the Holarctic and Oriental regions, and \i{}Microchaetes\i0{} occurs in Australia, New Zealand and southern South America. The genus \i{}Sierraclava\i0{} occurs in the Sierra Nevada, California.>
<Callirhipidae occur throughout the warmer parts of the world and are present on all continents, Madagascar, and some Pacific Islands, but not New Zealand.>
<True Cantharinae occur primarily in the Holarctic and Oriental regions, extending to southern Mexico in the New World and North Africa, India and the Sunda Archipelago in the Old World.>
<Chauliognathini occur throughout the New World from southern Canada to Chile, and in Australia and New Guinea.>
<Most Ichthyurini occur throughout the New and Old Worlds, but are absent from Australia and most of Europe.>

<Dysmorphocerine Cantharidae occur primarily in the Southern Hemisphere. In the New World they extend from Arizona to Chile, and in the Old World, they are known from southern Africa, Australia, New Guinea and New Zealand.>

<Malthinine Cantharidae occur from Canada to Brazil in the New World, throughout the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, and south to central and eastern Africa, India and the East Indies, with \i{}Caccodes\i0{} extending into the Pacific (including Hawaii). No malthinines occur in Australia, and a single species of \i{}Malthodes\i0{} (possibly introduced) is known from New Zealand.>
<Silinae Cantharidae occur mainly in tropical regions, with most species in the Northern Hemisphere, with diminished numbers in South America, South India, Africa and northern Australia.>
<The genus \i{}Tytthonyx\i0{} (= \i{}Thinalmus\i0{}) occurs from eastern North America to Central America and the West Indies.>
<Species of \i{}Cerophytum\i0{} are known from eastern North America, western Europe and tropical America.>
<\i{}Brounia thoracica\i0{} Sharp occurs on both North and South Islands, New Zealand.>
<Species of \i{}Chelonarium\i0{} occur in the warmer parts of the Western and Eastern Hemispheres, but they are more common in the New World tropics.>
<Species of \i{}Pseudochelonarium\i0{} occur throughout eastern Asia and the East Indies and as far south as New Guinea.>
<Species of \i{}Acalyptomerus\i0{} have been seen from Central America, eastern and southern Africa, Mauritius, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, southeast Asia and Australia.>
<Species of \i{}Calyptomerus\i0{} are native to the temperate parts of the Holarctic region, but the Palaearctic \i{}C. dubius\i0{} (Marsham) has been introduced into South Africa and Tasmania.>
<Clambinae are widely distributed, occurring on all continents and most larger islands.>
<Species of \i{}Cneoglossa\i0{} occur in the Neotropical region from Mexico to Brazil.>

<Dascillines occur throughout the Northern Hemisphere and in Australia, but are apparently absent from Africa and tropical America (except for an undescribed species from the Greater Antilles). The greatest diversity of Dascillinae is in Asia.>
<The genus \i{}Coptocera\i0{} (= \i{}Cinnabarium\i0{}) occurs in central western Africa and southeastern Asia.>
<Karumiines occur in the more arid parts of western North America, Mexico, temperate South America, North Africa and Eurasia.>
<The genus \i{}Genecerus\i0{} occurs in northern Africa and Asia Minor.>

<\i{}Declinia relicta\i0{} Nikitsky \i{}et al.\i0{} occurs along the eastern coast of Siberia from the Khasan District of the Maritime Province, south of Vladivostok, north to the floodplain of the Arman River, near Madagan. A second species, \i{}D. versicolor\i0{} Sakai & Satô occurs in Honshu and Shikoku, Japan.>

<Species of \i{}Drilus\i0{} are known from Europe, Africa, Asia Minor, Central Asia and Sri Lanka, \i{}Malacogaster\i0{} occurs in southern Europe, northern Africa, Asia Minor and the Canary Islands, \i{}Selasia\i0{} is restricted to Africa, and \i{}Pseudeuanoma\i0{} occurs in eastern Europe and Asia Minor.>

<Species of \i{}Drilus\i0{} are known from Europe, Africa, Asia Minor, Central Asia and Sri Lanka, \i{}Malacogaster\i0{} occurs in southern Europe, northern Africa, Asia Minor and the Canary Islands, \i{}Selasia\i0{} is restricted to Africa, and \i{}Pseudeuanoma\i0{} occurs in eastern Europe and Asia Minor.>
<Dryopidae occur in all major regions of the world but are absent from the continent of Australia.>
<\i{}Ceradryops punctatus\i0{} Hinton occurs in Sri Lanka, and \i{}Uenodryops himalayanus\i0{} Satô is known from Nepal.>
<\i{}Holcodryops mouli\i0{} Spangler is known only from Ecuador.>
<Two species of \i{}Quadryops\i0{} are known from Panama (Chiriqui Province and Canal Zone) and one is known from Ecuador.>
<Species of \i{}Spalacosostea\i0{} are known from Borneo and Sumatra.>
<Elateridae are cosmopolitan in distribution.>
<Agrypnine Elateridae are cosmopolitan in distribution.>
<Species of \i{}Danosoma\i0{} occur in the northern part of the Holarctic region.>
<Species of \i{}Octocryptus\i0{} are known from India, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<Cardiophorine Elateridae are cosmopolitan in distribution.>
<Cebrioninae occur in most parts of the world, but they are absent from Australia and New Zealand. They are particularly abundant in the more arid parts of the Holarctic Region.>
<This group contains those New Zealand species comprising the genera \i{}Amychus\i0{}, \i{}Psorochroa\i0{} and \i{}Acritelater\i0{} or currently placed in "\i{}Ctenicera\i0{}".>
<Members of the Adrastini occur in most parts of the world, but are absent from Australia and New Zealand.>

<Members of the Melanotini occur in all major regions of the world, but they are most abundant and diverse in the Holarctic and Oriental regions, relatively uncommon in South America, Africa and Australia, and absent from New Zealand.>
<The genera \i{}Odontonychus\i0{}, \i{}Odontonychoides\i0{} and \i{}Morphodontonychus\i0{} occur in eastern and central Africa.>
<The genus \i{}Eudicronyhcus\i0{} occurs in India, Sri Lanka and central to southern Africa. \i{}Anisomerus\i0{} and \i{}Tarsalgus\i0{} are both restricted to Africa.>
<The genera \i{}Hemiops\i0{}, \i{}Parhemiops\i0{} and \i{}PLectrosternus\i0{} occur in India, China, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<The genus \i{}Austrelater\i0{} occurs in eastern Australia, from Lord Howe Island and the Barrington Tops region, New South Wales, to the Bellenden Ker Range in northern Queensland.>
<Lissomine elaterids occur mainly in tropical and subtropical regions, but some \i{}Drapetes\i0{} occur in the cooler parts of the Holarctic region.>
<Two species of \i{}Paradrapetes\i0{} are known, one from Brazil and another from Bolivia.>
<The genus \i{}Oestodes\i0{} occurs across the north central and northeastern portion of North America from Alberta and North Dakota to New England and the Maritime Provinces.>
<The genera \i{}Protelater\i0{} and \i{}Sphaenelater\i0{} occur in New Zealand, and \i{}Anaspasis\i0{} is known from Chile.>

<Negastriine Elateridae occur in most regions of the world, but they are absent from New Zealand and represented in Australia only by an unusual and possibly misplaced genus coded separately (See \i{}Rivulicola\i0{}).>
<Species of \i{}Rivulicola\i0{} occur along the eastern and northern coasts of Australia.>
<Physodactylinae occur in South America, North Africa, central and southern Africa, India and Southeast Asia.>
<The genus \i{}Toxognathus\i0{} occurs in Southeast Asia.>

<The genus \i{}Pityobius\i0{} is restricted to North America, with one species in California, a second extending across the northern part of the continent, and a third in the southeastern United States.>
<The genus \i{}Oistus\i0{} includes one species from Oregon and several extending from Mexico to Ecuador.>
<Species of \i{}Semiotus\i0{} occur throughout tropical America from Mexico to Brazil and northern Argentina.>
<Species of \i{}Subprotelater\i0{} are known from southeast Asia, New Guinea and Australia.>
<Tetralobine Elateridae occur throughout the warmer parts of the Old World from central and southeastern Africa and Madagascar to Southeast Asia, the East Indies, New Guinea and Australia.>
<Thylacosternines are more or less tropicopolitan in distribution, occurring in tropical America, Africa, Asia and Australia.>
<The genus \i{}Athoomorphus\i0{} occurs in southern Africa.>
<\i{}Diplophoenicus alluaudi\i0{} Candèze is known from the Amber Mountains on Magadascar.>
<The genus \i{}Pleonomoides\i0{} occurs in southern Africa.>
<The Elminae are more or less cosmopolitan in distribution, occurring wherever there are appropriate types of freshwater habitats; however they have not been recorded from New Zealand.>
<Laraine Elmidae occur in all major regions of the world.>
<The three species of \i{}Jaechomorphus\i0{} areknown only from Sumatra.>
<Eucinetidae is a widely distributed family.>
<\i{}Bisaya nossidiiformis\i0{} Reitter is known from Iran.>
<\i{}Jentozkus\i0{} is a Neotropical genus, occurring from southern Mexico to Brazil. Species of \i{}Tohlezkus\i0{} occur in Turkey, Japan, Taiwan and the southeastern United States.>
<Eucnemidae occur in all major regions of the world, although many taxa are rare in collections.>
<The genus \i{}Perothops\i0{} occurs in North America.>
<The genus \i{}Phyllocerus\i0{} occurs from southeastern Europe, the Caucasus and Central Asia to southern Africa and Madagascar.>
<\i{}Schizophilus subrufus\i0{} (Randall) occurs in the eastern United States and Canada.>
<Species of \i{}Eulichas\i0{} occur in China and southeast Asia, while \i{}Stenocolus scutellaris\i0{} LeConte is restricted to California.>
<The genus \i{}Elythomerus\i0{} is known only from the Rockhampton area in Queensland.>
<Heterocerids are common in most regions of the world.>
<The genus \i{}Micilus\i0{} is known from Europe and Asia.>
<Lampyrinae occur in all major regions of the world, but are absent from Australia and New Zealand.>
<Lampyrinae occur in all major regions of the world, but are absent from Australia and New Zealand.>
<Lampyrinae occur in all major regions of the world, but are absent from Australia and New Zealand.>
<Species of \i{}Amydetes\i0{} occur from Mexico to Brazil.>
<Species of \i{}Magnoculus\i0{} (= \i{}Megalophthalmus\i0{}) occur throughout the Neotropical region from Mexico to Argentina.>
<Species of \i{}Patalacmis\i0{} are known from Peru, Bolivia and Brazil.>
<\i{}Phosphaenus hemipterus\i0{} (Fourcroy) occurs in western Europe, but has also been reported from Nova Scotia (Brown 1950).>

<The Luciolinae are restricted to the warmer parts of the Old World, occurring from southern Europe and Asia Minor to southern Africa and Madagascar, Japan, Southeast Asia, the East Indies, New Guinea, Australia and some Pacific islands.>
<Brachelytrous females are rare in Luciolinae, occurring in a few species of \i{}Atyphella\i0{} from Australia and New Guinea and in \i{}Bourgeoisia hypocrita\i0{} Olivier from Fiji.>
<Species of \i{}Ototretadrilus\i0{} are known from India, Southeast Asia, the Philippines, and the East Indies.>

<Ototretine Lampyridae are known from western North America and from the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions (from Japan and China, to India, Southeast Asia, the Philippines and the East Indies.>
<The genus \i{}Harmatelia\i0{} occurs only in Sri Lanka.>
<Photurine Lampyridae occur throughout the New World from Canada to Argentina.>
<\i{}Pterotus obscuripennis\i0{} LeConte occurs from western Washington and Oregon to northern Baja California; \i{}P. curticornis\i0{} Chemsak is known from Riverise Co. in southern California.>
<\i{}Pterotus obscuripennis\i0{} LeConte occurs from western Washington and Oregon to northern Baja California; \i{}P. curticornis\i0{} Chemsak is known from Riverise Co. in southern California.>

<The genus \i{}Cephalobyrrhus\i0{} is known from Japan and India. \i{}Throscinus\i0{} is a New World genus with species from the Gulf Coast of North America, coastal Mexico, the West Indies and northern South America. \i{}Parathroscinus\i0{} occurs in the Oriental region and northern Australia, and one species has been introduced into the Hawaiian Islands.>
<Species of \i{}Hyphalus\i0{} are known from the northeastern coasts of Australia and North Island, New Zealand, Norfolk and Lord Howe Islands, and the Ryukyu Archipelago, Japan.>
<Limnichine Limnichidae are cosmopolitan in distribution.>
<The genus \i{}Ersachus\i0{} occurs from Mexico to northern South America.>
<The genus \i{}Paralimnichus\i0{} is known from Panama, the Philippines, Sabah, the Bismarck Archipelago, Solomon Is. and eastern Australia.>
<Thaumastodine Limnichidae are known from the West Indies, western Mexico, Japan, southeast Asia, the East Indies and northern Australia.>
<Species of \i{}Lutrochus\i0{} occur from the central United States south to Brazil.>
<Lycidae occur in all major regions of the world, but are most diverse in tropical and subtropical areas.>
<The genus \i{}Calochromus\i0{} occurs in the eastern Palaearctic, Oriental and Australian regions.>
<Species of \i{}Duliticola\i0{} and \i{}Platerodrilus\i0{} are known from India, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<Species of \i{}Duliticola\i0{} and \i{}Platerodrilus\i0{} are known from India, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<Leptolycine Lycidae occur in the New World tropics, from the West Indies to Colombia and Peru.>
<The genus \i{}Lypropaeus\i0{} occurs throughout the Oriental region from India and Sri Lanka to Southeast Asia, the Philippines and the East Indies.>
<\i{}Metriorhynchus apterus\i0{} Lea is known only from Darling Downs, Queensland.>
<Species of \i{}Omalisus\i0{}, \i{}Phaeopterus\i0{} and \i{}Thilmanus\i0{} occur in central, southern and eastern Europe.>
<Species of \i{}Drilonius\i0{} occur in the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions from Japan to Java and Sumatra.>

<\i{}Matheteus theveneti\i0{} LeConte occurs from central Califormia (Monterey and Mariposa Counties) north to southwestern Oregon. Two species of \i{}Ginglymocladus\i0{} occur in montane and costal California.>

<Omethinae are restricted to the Nearctic and eastern Palaearctic regions. The genus \i{}Omethes\i0{} occurs in northeastern North America and Japan, \i{}Blatchleya\i0{} is known from Indiana, and \i{}Malthomethes\i0{}, \i{}Troglomethes\i0{} and \i{}Symphyomethes\i0{} occur in northwestern North America.>
<Phengodidae are distributed throughout the New World from extreme southern Canada to Chile (SEE Taxon Notes).>
<Phengodidae are distributed throughout the New World from extreme southern Canada to Chile (SEE Taxon Notes).>
<The genus \i{}Penicillophorus\i0{} is known from Colombia and Peru, and \i{}Adrendrocera\i0{} is known from Guatemala.>
<The genus \i{}Plastocerus\i0{} is known from Asia Minor and southeast Asia.>
<\i{}Podabrocephalus sinuaticollis\i0{} Pic is known only from India.>
<Eubrianacine Psephenidae occur in Asia and Africa, western North America and Peru.>
<Eubriinae are widely distributed but most diverse in the Oriental Region.>
<Species of \i{}Eubria\i0{} are known from Europe and Asia.>
<The genus \i{}Sclerocyphon\i0{} is widespread in eastern Australia, and the closely related \i{}Tychepsephus\i0{} occurs in Chile.>
<Psepheninae occur from North America south to Brazil and in Asia.>
<Species of \i{}Psephenoides\i0{} occur in Asia, and \i{}Afropsephenoides\i0{} is knowm from Africa.>
<Ptilodactylidae occur in most areas of the world, but are absent from Europe.>
<\i{}Araeopidius monachus\i0{} (LeConte) occurs in the northwestern part of North America from Alaska south to central California.>
<\i{}Drupeus\i0{} species have been described from Japan but are also known from China and Taiwan.>
<\i{}Octoglossa\i0{} species are known from Central and South America.>
<Ptilodactylinae occur in most parts of the world, especially in warmer regions. They are not native to Europe, but one species is known as a greenhouse pest in Italy (Süss and Puppin 1976).>
<Rhagophthalmidae occur throughout the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions from Japan to India, Sri Lanka and the East Indies.>
<Rhagophthalmidae occur throughout the eastern Palaearctic and Oriental regions from Japan to India, Sri Lanka and the East Indies.>
<Species of \i{}Diplocladon\i0{} occur in India, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<Species of \i{}Diplocladon\i0{} occur in India, Southeast Asia and the East Indies.>
<The genus \i{}Dodecatoma\i0{} ocurs in India, the Philippines and the East Indies.>
<The genus \i{}Rhinorhipus\i0{} is restricted to northern New South Wales and southern Queensland, Australia.>

<Rhipiceridae occur in all major regions of the world, but they are not very common in collections. The genus \i{}Sandalus\i0{} is known from North and South America, China, Japan, India, Southeast Asia and Africa, \i{}Rhipicera\i0{} occurs in Australia, New Caledonia and Brazil, \i{}Ptiocerus\i0{} is restricted to South Africa, \i{}Arrhaphipterus\i0{} ranges from southeaster Europe to central Asia, and \i{}Polymerius\i0{} is endemic to Chile.>
<Scirtidae are cosmopolitan in distribution but are far more diverse in the cool temperate parts of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, and relatively uncommon in tropical climates.>
<The genus \i{}Amplectopus\i0{} is restricted to New Zealand.>
<The genus \i{}Scirtes\i0{} and its relatives are distributed throughout the warmer parts of the world and do not occur in Chile or New Zealand.>
<\i{}Telegeusis\i0{} is distributed from the southwestern United States to Panama, and species of \i{}Pseudotelegeusis\i0{} are known from Trinidad and Ecuador.>
<Throscidae occur in most parts of the world, but have not been reported from New Zealand.>
<\i{}Neocrowsonia viatoricus\i0{} Kistner & Abdel-Galil is known only from the Cape Province of South Africa.>
<\i{}Pactopus horni\i0{} LeConte occurs in western North America, from British Columbia and northern Idaho to southern California.>
<The genus \i{}Potergus\i0{} is known from India, Southeast Asia, the Philippines, the East Indies, Seychelles, New Guinea and Australia.>
<Species of \i{}Cydistus\i0{} are known from Turkey, Syria and Iran.>

<biology>
data: <Nothing has been published on the biology of \i{}Anischia\i0{}; however adults were collected in Panama from a fungus on the surface of a log, adults and an associated larva were found by sifting rotten wood and litter and associated with bracket fungi in New Caledonia, and Australian adults were taken by pyrethrin fogging logs.>

<Larvae of \i{}Artematopus\i0{} have been found in soil and observed to feed on dead insects in the laboratory. \i{}Macropogon\i0{} and \i{}Eurypogon\i0{} larvae have been found under mosses growing on rocks, but there is no clear cut evidence on feeding habits.>
<Nothing is known on the biology of \i{}Electribius\i0{}.>
<\i{}Brachypsectra\i0{} adults are not commonly collected. The strongly flattened larvae are ambush predators, living under loose bark or stones and feeding on spiders and other small arthropods.>

<Larvae of many Agrilinae bore beneath the bark of trunks and branches of a wide variety of trees and shrubs, but others live in galls on stems. Several \i{}Agrilus\i0{} species are pests of forest trees and ornamental trees and shrubs.>

<Larvae of \i{}Aphanisticus\i0{} in Europe are known to mine the leaves of monocots, such as Juncaceae and Cyperaceae, and \i{}A. cochinchinae seminulum\i0{} Obenberger attacks sugarcane leaves in Hawaii (Wellso 1995). South African \i{}Anthaxomorphus\i0{} species have been reared from \i{}Ficus\i0{} leaves (Bellamy 1987).>
<Larvae of \i{}Brachys\i0{} in North America are known to mine the leaves of oak (\i{}Quercus\i0{}), and \i{}Taphrocerus\i0{} has been associated with herbs, grasses and palms.>
<Cylindromorphines are stem miners in grasses.>

<Adults have been associated with \i{}Acacia\i0{} (Mimosaceae), \i{}Asparagus\i0{} (Liliaceae), \i{}Cordia\i0{} (Ehretiaceae) and \i{}Zizyphus\i0{} (Rhamnaceae), and putative larvae have been described from \i{}Acacia\i0{} wood (Mateu 1974).>

<\i{}Germarica\i0{} species are likely to be leaf-miners, but hosts have not been recorded. Bellamy (1992) mentions the possibility of their mining the needle-like leaves of \i{}Casuarina\i0{} (Casuarinaceae).>

<\i{}Pachyschelus\i0{} species in North America are known to mine the leaves of \i{}Lespedeza\i0{} (Fabaceae), and those in Southeast Asia have been reported to mine leaves of oaks. \i{}Hylaeogena\i0{} has been associated with Bignoniaceae.>

<Trachyini mine the leaves of a variety of dicotyledonous angiosperms, including members of the families Dipsaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Geraniaceae, Lamiaceae, Malvaceae and Rosaceae. The Neotropical genus \i{}Neotrachys\i0{} has been associated with tree ferns.>

<Adult Buprestinae feed primarily on the foliage of their host plants, but floricolous habits are known in the tribes Acmaeoderini, Anthaxiini and Stigmoderini. Buprestine larvae are wood borers, attacking living or dead trees or shrubs. Larvae may attack various parts of the host plant and hosts include gymnosperms, monocots and dicots. Some \i{}Buprestis\i0{} species oviposit in conifers and may continue their development for long periods in seasoned wood, emerging from structural wood as much as 50 years later.>

<\i{}Julodimorpha bakewelli\i0{} (White) has been recorded breeding in the roots and trunks of mallee (\i{}Eucalyptus\i0{} sp.) (Carter 1929). Adults were observed ovipositing 2.5 cm below the surface of damp soil near the base of a \i{}Calothamnus\i0{} (Myrtaceae) (Hawkeswood and Peterson 1982). Male \i{}Julodimorpha\i0{} have been seen attempting copulation with beer bottles; the color of the bottle and the pitting at its base apparently mimic the color and texture of the elytra.>
<Little is known about the biology or immature stages of Mastogeniini; however a North American \i{}Mastogenius\i0{} has been reported to breed in "small branches of oak" (Baker 1972).>

<Both \i{}Mendizabalia\i0{} and \i{}Philandia\i0{} species have been collected in association with \i{}Nothofagus\i0{}. The latter have unusually colored, pink and black prothoraces and black elytra, and are apparently in a Müllerian ring also including \i{}Pyractonema\i0{} (Lampyridae), \i{}Eucaliga\i0{} (Tenebrionidae: Alleculinae), \i{}Mecopselaphus\i0{} and \i{}Platylytra\i0{} (Oedemeridae).>
<\i{}Paratrachys\i0{} are leaf-miners of figs (\i{}Ficus\i0{} spp., Moraceae).>
<Larvae of \i{}Thrincopyge\i0{} species bore in the flower stalks of monocots in the genera \i{}Nolina\i0{} (Nolinaceae) and \i{}Dasylirion\i0{} (Agavaceae).>
<SEE Buprestinae (major part).>

<Both species of \i{}Xyroscelis\i0{} have been associated with cycads (\i{}Macrozamia\i0{} spp., Zamiaceae); adults are known to feed on sap produced by the host plant, and it is likely that larvae bore into the fronds.>
<Adult Julodinae are often found in numbers on feeding on foliage. Eggs are laid in the soil and larvae are root feeders.>
<Adult Schizopodinae may be found on flowers or foliage, and their larvae occur in the soil and probably feed on roots.>
<Larval and adult \i{}Amphicyrta\i0{} feed on the roots of a variety of herbaceous plants.>

<Most Byrrhinae feed on the leaves and rhizoids of mosses and liverworts (Bryophyta) and a few have been associated with lichens or higher plants. Some European \i{}Byrrhus\i0{} have been found in soil with seedlings in nurseries. An undescribed Australian byrrhine is known to feed on the rosettes of \i{}Cardamine\i0{} (Cruciferae) and has been implicated in the spread of a plant virus (Guy and Gibbs 1985).>
<Syncalyptines are bryophagous and are usually found in sandy soil which is covered with fine matts composed of mosses.>
<Larval callirhipids feed in dead wood and adults may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Adult Cantharinae, like those of most Cantharidae, are diurnal and occur on foliage and flowers. They are known to be facultative predators but may also feed on plant matter. They are usually brightly colored, and have a well-developed system of defense glands. Larvae are abundant in soil and litter, and are also either predaceous or phytophagous.>

<Adult chauliognathines are usually diurnal and may occur in large numbers on flowers or foliage. Larvae are usually found in leaf litter or other accumulations of vegetable debris; they are primarily predaceous but their abundance suggests that, like some Cantharinae, they may be faculative herbivores.>
<Nothing is known about the biology of Ichthyurini.>
<Like most cantharids, dysmorphocerines are diurnal and are often swept from foliage, while larvae occur in litter.>

<Because of their small size, there are few biological observations on Malthinini; however it is likely that the larvae are predaceous. According to Fender (1951), adults are often found on foliage in shaded situations.>
<Like most cantharids, adults occur on foliage or flowers and larvae are predators in leaf litter.>
<Nothing is known about the biology or immature stages of \i{}Tytthonyx\i0{}.>

<Larvae of \i{}Cerophytum elateroides\i0{} Latreille have been collected in old decomposing (brown rotten) wood of elm (\i{}Ulmus\i0{}) and alder (\i{}Alnus\i0{}). Adults are capable of "clicking" like Elateridae and other related groups.>
<The biology of \i{}Brounia thoracica\i0{} is unknown.>

<\i{}Chelonarium\i0{} larvae have been found in leaf litter, debris at the bases of orchids, epiphytic ant plants, nests of mound-building ants, army ant refuse heaps, and dead branches, and occasionally under bark.>
<The habits and immature stages of \i{}Pseudochelonarium\i0{} are not known.>
<\i{}Acalyptomerus\i0{} larvae and adults have been collected in leaf litter, hay stacks and other accumulations of organic debris. Adults have also been collected in bracket fungi.>
<\i{}Calyptomerus dubius\i0{} (Marsham) occurs in haystacks and feeds on molds.>
<Clambines are mycetophagus and some have been associated with Myxomycetes.>
<Larvae of \i{}Cneoglossa edsoni\i0{} Costa \i{}et al.\i0{} (1999) were found in rotting brushwood in shallow flowing streams; pupae and adults were reared in the laboratory.>
<Larvae of \i{}Dascillus\i0{} and \i{}Notodascillus\i0{} are found in the soil and apparently feed on roots; they resemble scarab grubs.>
<Nothing has been recorded on the biology of \i{}Coptocera\i0{} species.>
<At least some karumiines are known to be termitophiles, and similar habits may occur in all of them. It is likely that larvae occur in the soil, probably associated with subterranean termites.>
<Nothing is known of the life history of \i{}Genecerus\i0{}.>

<Adults of \i{}Declinia relicta\i0{} were collected in flight intercept traps and had pollen grains in the gut; some adults of the Japanese species were collected on the leaves of dwarf bamboo, together with a species of \i{}Cyphon\i0{}. The immature stages are unknown.>
<Larvae of \i{}Drilus\i0{} and \i{}Selasia\i0{} are known to feed on snails; females lack elytra and are more or less larviform.>
<Larvae of \i{}Drilus\i0{} and \i{}Selasia\i0{} are known to feed on snails; females lack elytra and are more or less larviform.>

<Dryopids usually occur in wetter habitats, but only the adults of \i{}Helichus\i0{}, \i{}Postelichus\i0{} and \i{}Elmoparnus\i0{}, and all stages of \i{}Stygoparnus\i0{} are known to be truly aquatic. Most dryopid larvae occur in soil or leaf litter.>
<The single known adult of \i{}Holcodryops mouli\i0{} was collected on a plant in the splash zone of a waterfall.>
<Adults of \i{}Quadryops\i0{} have been collected in forest litter and by sweeping vegetation and fogging forest canopy.>
<Adults of \i{}Spalacosostea\i0{} have been collected in forest litter.>

<Adult elaterids are often found on foliage or bark surfaces and may feed on plant shoots or tips, nectar or possibly epiphytic microflora. Larvae are liquid feeders utilizing extra-oral digestion, but they may be either predaceous or phytophagous; they occur under bark or rocks and in rotten wood, leaf litter or soil. Soil-dwelling larvae or wireworms may be serious pests of agricultural crops.>

<Adult Agrypninae are usually found on bark or leaf surfaces or in leaf litter, but little is known of their feeding habits. Larvae occur under bark or stones, or in rotten wood, leaf litter or soil. Some agrypnine larvae, particularly the larger, wood-inhabiting forms, are predaceous, but others occur in the soil, feed on roots of various plants, and may damage crops.>
<Larvae of \i{}Danosoma\i0{} occur in wood and probably prey on wood-boring insects.>
<\i{}Octocryptus\i0{} adults are found in leaf liter and immature stages are unknown.>
<Larvae of Cardiophorinae occur in soil and are very distinctive, with a very slender, worm-like body and peculiar, externally toothed mandibles; these larvae are predaceous.>

<Male Cebrioninae fly at night and may be attracted to lights. In several genera, including \i{}Cebrio\i0{}, \i{}Selonodon\i0{} and \i{}Euthysanius\i0{}, females are flightless, and other groups are known from males only. All known larvae live in the soil.>
<SEE ELATERIDAE (major part).>
<Adrastine larvae occur in soil and litter, sometimes at the margins of bodies of water but usually in forested areas.>

<Adult melanotines, like most elaterids, occur on foliage and flowers, and some may feed on nectar. Known larvae may live in decaying wood and may be predaceous, but many have been recorded in soil feeding on roots and causing damage to cereal and forage crops and sugar cane.>
<A female \i{}Odontonychoides\i0{} from Zambia (Natural History Museum, London) was found sealed in a cell in a termite mound.>
<Larvae of \i{}Austrelater\i0{} feed in decaying wood.>
<Lissomine larvae feed in decaying wood.>
<\i{}Oestodes\i0{} larvae are soil-inhabiting wireworms and are known to feed on wheat and oats.>
<Larvae of Protelaterini occur in rotten wood, and those of \i{}Sphaenelater\i0{} have been observed feeding on fly larvae.>
<Adult negastriines are often found on vegetation, and larvae live in leaf litter or soil, often in riparian situations. The larval feeding habits are not known.>
<Adult \i{}Rivulicola\i0{} occur in riparian situations, along the banks of rivers, streams, lakes and ponds.>

<Larvae of \i{}Pityobius\i0{} occur under bark and in the wood of rotten trees. Like many other elaterids, \i{}Pityobius\i0{} appear to be facultative predators. Larvae will feed on mealworms, but can be reared on moist wood frass found in tunnels of termites and wood-boring beetles.>
<Nothing has been published on the biology or immature stages of \i{}Oistus\i0{}.>
<\i{}Semiotus\i0{} larvae are usually found in moist, sappy areas under bark, and have been observed feeding on fly larvae.>
<Nothing is known on the biology of \i{}Subprotelater\i0{}.>

<Tetralobinae larvae are associated with the nests of termites. They have been recorded from the nests of Termitidae (\i{}Nasutitermes\i0{} and \i{}Macrotermes\i0{}) and Rhinotermitidae (\i{}Coptotermes\i0{}) in Africa and Australia.>
<Thylacosternine larvae feed in dead wood.>

<Elminae are are fully aquatic as adults and larvae, usually occurring in sand, gravel, or submerged wood in streams. Some feed on algae and detritus, while others attack woody surfaces, making them more suitable for further breakdown by microorganisms and other aquatic invertebrates (McKie and Cranston 1998). All adults have a ventral plastron consisting of fine hydrofuge hairs.>

<Laraine larvae are all aquatic, occurring in rivers and streams and feeding on detritus. Many adults are also aquatic, but those of \i{}Lara\i0{}, \i{}Phanocerus\i0{} and some other genera occur in riparian situations and enter the water only for oviposition.>
<Adult \i{}Jaechomorphus\i0{} were all collected in small streams or springs in montane forests.>

<Eucinetids are usually collected in leaf litter, rotten wood, or under the bark of decaying logs. Both adults and larvae are mycetophagous, but some specialize on the spores of slime molds, some feed on the hyphae of Basidiomycetes, and others are associated with various types of decaying plant material.>
<\i{}Bisaya nossidiiformis\i0{} Reitter has been collected in dead wood and litter.>
<Like most eucinetids, these minute forms are associated with rotting wood, leaf litter and fungi; they are thought to feed on fungal hyphae using their piercing mouthparts.>

<Adult Eucnemidae are usually collected on plant surfaces, at lights at night, or in flight-intercept traps. Larvae of most taxa occur in dead wood and are capable of moving through fairly solid wood by forcing their bodies between wood fibers; however some are soil-dwelling (see Phyllocerini and Perothopinae). Eucnemid larvae are liquid feeders, so their actual diet is difficult to ascertain. It is possible that they feed on the plasmodium of Myxomycetes, or digest plant tissue extra-orally.>
<The habits and immatures stages of \i{}Perothops\i0{} species are not yet known.>
<Larvae of \i{}Phyllocerus\i0{} species occur in the soil and feed on plant roots.>
<\i{}Schizophilus subrufus\i0{} adults have been observed on the bark of \i{}Fagus\i0{}.>
<Eulichadid larvae are aquatic, occurring among dead leaves in streams.>
<Nothing is known about the biology of \i{}Elythomerus\i0{}.>
<Adult and larval Heteroceridae construct tunnels in wet sand at the edges of streams and ponds and feed on algae. Adults are often attracted to lights at night.>
<Nothing is recorded of the biology of \i{}Micilus\i0{}.>

<Lampyrinae includes most of the typical fireflies, which may be luminescent as adults and larvae; however light organs are absent in many groups or in some species of typically luminescent genera, such as \i{}Photinus\i0{}. Lampyrine larvae are predaceous, feeding on a variety of soft-bodied invertebrates, such as earthworms, snails and slugs or arthropods. It is likely that most species do not feed as adults.>

<Lampyrinae includes most of the typical fireflies, which may be luminescent as adults and larvae; however light organs are absent in many groups or in some species of typically luminescent genera, such as \i{}Photinus\i0{}. Lampyrine larvae are predaceous, feeding on a variety of soft-bodied invertebrates, such as earthworms, snails and slugs or arthropods. It is likely that most species do not feed as adults.>

<Lampyrinae includes most of the typical fireflies, which may be luminescent as adults and larvae; however light organs are absent in many groups or in some species of typically luminescent genera, such as \i{}Photinus\i0{}. Lampyrine larvae are predaceous, feeding on a variety of soft-bodied invertebrates, such as earthworms, snails and slugs or arthropods. It is likely that most species do not feed as adults.>
<Male \i{}Magnoculus\i0{} have luminescent organs at the apex of the abdomen, and females are unknown.>

<In almost all Luciolinae both sexes are winged and luminescent, and synchronous flashing has been observed in some groups. Adults are not known to feed, but larvae are predators of small land snails.>
<SEE Luciolinae (major part).>
<\i{}Ototretadrilus\i0{} are known only from males and nothing is known of the immature stages or habits.>
<Little is known on the biology of ototretines. They are not thought to be luminous, although \i{}Brachylampis\i0{} has the last 3 ventrites pale in color.>
<Adult males of \i{}Harmatelia\i0{} have small, paired light organs on ventrites 1 to 8 and on the mesopleuron. Females and larvae are unknown.>

<Most photurines, like other fireflies, are predaceous as adults and larvae, and adults of some \i{}Photuris\i0{} feed on other members of the Lampyridae. Both male and female photurines are winged and possess luminescent organs, which are used to attract mates or in some cases lampyrid prey. At least one species of \i{}Photuris\i0{} from Brazil is known to feed as larvae on the guano of haematophagous bats (Gnaspini and Trajano, in press).>
<Larval \i{}Pterotus\i0{} feed primarily on slugs, while adults may not feed.>
<Larval \i{}Pterotus\i0{} feed primarily on slugs, while adults may not feed.>
<Little is known on the biology of cephalobyrrhines, but all species are coastal and it is likely that they have similar habits to the Thaumastodinae.>

<\i{}Hyphalus\i0{} inhabit marine littoral and intertidal zones, where they may be found on the undersides of rocks which are either submerged moistened by waves at high tide. They apparently feed on blue-green algae.>
<Limnichine larvae live in damp soil or leaf litter, usually near bodies of water. Adults may be collected in flood debris, but are more commonly taken at light.>
<Nothing is known on the biology of \i{}Ersachus\i0{}.>
<Nothing is known on the biology or immature stages of \i{}Paralimnichus\i0{}.>

<Thaumastodines, like cephalobyrrhines, occur along coasts in the marine littoral zone. Adults of an undescribed species from Christmas Island, Indian Ocean, were collected on wet sand along a rocky coastline. Larvae were found tunneling in the sand, which was continually moistened by ocean spray.>
<\i{}Lutrochus\i0{} larvae are inhabitants of freshwater habitats and typically burrow into calcareous encrustations produced by algae in shallow rapids.>

<Lycid adults are commonly seen flying at dusk and may be found in flowers or on foliage. Some adults may be nectar-feeders, but others probably do not feed at all. Larvae and occur under bark or in leaf litter; they are liquid feeders, but there is little reliable information on their diet.>

<Duliticolines exhibit extreme sexual dimorphism and neoteny. Females are much larger than males and completely larviform. The peculiar flattened form, enlarged thorax and lateral abdominal processes of larvae and females of this group have earned them the name "trilobite larvae".>

<Larvae and larviform females of \i{}Duliticola\i0{} species are well known inhabitants of tropical forests, where they usually occur on the surfaces of logs. Their peculiar form has earned them the name "trilobite larvae". Their feeding habits, like those of most Lycidae, are uncertain; however they appear to suck juices from rotting plant material.>
<Nothing is known on the biology or immature states of Leptolycini.>

<Little is known about the life history of \i{}Lypropaeus\i0{}, although larvae were described and figured by Gravely (1925). Since only adult males are known, it is possible that females are larviform.>
<SEE LYCIDAE (major part).>
<Larvae of \i{}Omalisus fontisbellaquei\i0{} Fourcroy feed on millipedes of the genus \i{}Glomeris\i0{}.>
<Nothing is known about the biology or immature stages of \i{}Drilonius\i0{}.>
<Adult matheteines have been collected on foliage, but nothing is known about their biology or immature stages.>
<Omethinae are relatively rare and nothing is known on their biology or immature stages.>

<Larval and female Phengodidae are predators, feeding on millipedes and other arthropods occurring in soil and litter. The winged males, which are often attracted to lights at night, are short-lived and probably do not feed. Females are much larger than the males and are completely larviform. Males may be luminescent, but females and larvae have a series of luminescent organs on trunk segments, which emit yellow or green light, and sometimes an additional head organ, which emits red light.>

<Larval and female Phengodidae are predators, feeding on millipedes and other arthropods occurring in soil and litter. The winged males, which are often attracted to lights at night, are short-lived and probably do not feed. Females are much larger than the males and are completely larviform. Males may be luminescent, but females and larvae have a series of luminescent organs on trunk segments, which emit green light, and sometimes an additional head organ, which emits red light.>
<Nothing is known about the biology of Penicillophorini.>
<Nothing is known of the biology or immature stages of \i{}Plastocerus\i0{}.>
<Nothing is known on the biology of \i{}Podabrocephalus\i0{}.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<Larval Psephenidae cling to rocks in fast-moving streams and graze on algae; their flattened, disk-like shape has earned them the name "water pennies". Adults, which are short-lived, occur on stream-side vegetation and may be attracted to lights at night.>

<With some exceptions (SEE Ptilodactylinae), Ptilodactylidae live in riparian, semiaquatic and aquatic habitats, and their larvae often have various adaptations for survival under water, such as anal gills or a spiracular siphon. Adults are often collected on riparian vegetation or in flight-intercept traps. In some groups (e.g. \i{}Daemon\i0{}, \i{}Aploglossa\i0{}) they have maxillary brushes for feeding on surface microfungi (Stribling and Seymour 1988).>

<Larvae of \i{}Araeopidius monachus\i0{} live among rocks and gravel in and adjacent to streams and rivers. They probably feed on dead plant material, and have special adaptations (plastron plates) to survive flooding.>
<Nothing is known about the biology of \i{}Drupeus\i0{}.>
<Nothing is known about the biology or immature stages of \i{}Octoglossa\i0{}.>

<Ptilodactyline adults are often found on foliage and feed on microfungi; their maxillae are modified to form brushes for handling spores and loose hyphae (Stribling and Seymour 1988). Their larvae occur in leaf litter or dead wood, often in wetter environments. Unlike some other members of the family, these larvae do not have special adaptations for surviving under water.>
<Rhagophthalmid larvae occur in soil and litter and are predaceous. Females are apterous with adult eyes, antennae and legs. Larvae and females are luminescent.>

<Rhagophthalmid larvae occur in soil and litter and are predaceous. Females are apterous with adult eyes, antennae and legs. Larvae and females are luminescent. The major light organ in female \i{}Dioptoma\i0{} is located on sternite 7.>

<\i{}Diplocladon\i0{} larvae and larviform females are soil- and litter-dwelling predators which have 3 small photogenic organs on most body segments; they are commonly called star-worms. Male light organs appear to be present on the first five or six abdominal ventrites and occupy most of the central portion of each ventrite.>

<\i{}Diplocladon\i0{} females are completely larviform and occur with the larvae in soil and litter. They have three small light organs on all trunk segments, except the last two, which have two and one, respectively; these organs emit a greenish-blue light.>

<Males are attracted to lights at night. Their light organ appears to occupy the central portions of the first three or four abdominal ventrites (based on the whitish color of these areas on dried specimens).>
<Adult \i{}Rhinorhipus\i0{} may be collected in early Spring on the surfaces of vegetation; immature stages are unknown.>

<Adult Rhipiceridae are occasionally encountered in large numbers flying during the day. \i{}Sandalus niger\i0{} Knoch is known to lay eggs in bark crevices, and the first instar triungulin larvae attach to cicada nymphs before they enter the soil and transform into ectoparasitic larvae. It is likely that other rhipicerids are also cicada parasites, but this has not been documented.>

<Adult Scirtidae are usually encountered on plant surfaces, but they are relatively short-lived. Larvae are usually aquatic, occurring in still water, such as ponds, lakes or tree holes; a few Southern Hemisphere forms, however, have been copllected in moist, rotten wood well away from water.>
<\i{}Amplectopus\i0{} adults have been collected in leaf litter. Larvae are undescribed.>

<Adult \i{}Scirtes\i0{} and \i{}Ora\i0{} are usually collected on the surfaces of vegetation, while their larvae live in ponds. Adults of this group are capable of jumping using the enlarged hind legs.>
<Nothing is known on the biology and immature stages of Telegeusidae.>
<Throscid larvae are often taken in the soil, where they feed on ectomycorrhizal fungi on the roots of various trees; however some have been collected in rotten conifer wood and grass tufts.>
<\i{}Neocrowsonia\i0{} adults have been collected in the nests of the termite \i{}Microhodotermes viator\i0{} (Latreille); immature stages are unknown.>
<Larvae of \i{}Pactopus horni\i0{} are unknown, but pupae and adults have been collected under a debarked log in a heavily burned area.>
<Nothing is known on the biology or immature stages of \i{}Potergus\i0{}.>
<Only male \i{}Cydistus\i0{} are known, and it is likely that females are larviform.>

characters.name: <notes>
data: <The genus \i{}Anischia\i0{} Fleutiaux (1896) was described as a eucnemid, but has usually been placed in Cerophytidae based mainly on the absence of metacoxal plates. Lawrence and Newton (1995) tentatively placed the genus in Elateridae, but it has become evident that although the taxon belongs within the Elateroidea, it cannot be accommodated in any of the presently recognized families (Muona 1995). The larva, which resembles those of some of the more basal Eucnemidae, is currently being described as part of an analysis of the elateroid complex (Muona and Lawrence, in preparation).>

<\i{}Brachypsectra\i0{} has been placed within various elateriform superfamilies, but in most recent cladograms (Beutel 1995; Lawrence 1988, Lawrence \i{}et al.\i0{} 1995), it appears to cluster with the cantharoid complex, the elateroid complex or both (Elateroidea in the sense of Lawrence 1988).>

<The major portion of the Agrilinae is comprised of two main lineages: Agrilini, including among others the very large genus \i{}Agrilus\i0{} (at least 4000 species), and Coroebini, with more than 150 genera from all parts of the world and a number of mainly undescribed genera from Madagascar (C. L. Bellamy, \i{}in litt.\i0{}).>
<The genus \i{}Galbella\i0{} may represent a transitional lineage between Buprestinae and Agrilinae (C. L. Bellamy, \i{}in litt.\i0{}).>
<This species is coded separately because of its 10-segmented antennae.>
<\i{}Paratrachys\i0{} appears to be related to the Afrotropical genus \i{}Sponsor\i0{} and to \i{}Ptomisa\i0{} from the Palaearctic and Oriental regions (C. L. Bellamy, \i{}in litt.\i0{}).>

<This ITEM is based on those genera of Anthaxiini (Buprestinae) which have extreme antennal dimorphism, with the male antennae being pectinate to flabellate or plumose. The New World genera probably form a monophyletic group, but \i{}Australorhipis\i0{} may be more closely related to \i{}Notographus\i0{} species, which do not have modified antennae in the male.>

<Callirhipidae were traditionally included in the same family as Rhipiceridae (Sandalidae of Emden), but Böving and Craighead (1931) considered the \i{}Zenoa\i0{} larva to be quite distinct from that of \i{}Sandalus\i0{} and placed the two genera in different families. Forbes (1926) placed the callirhipids in the family Eulichadidae (as Lichadidae) based on wing venation. Crowson (1950, 1955) recognized a superfamily Rhipiceroidea which included both Rhipiceridae and Callirhipidae, but later (1971, 1973) united the former with Dascillidae and placed the latter in a new superfamily Artematopidae, along with two other basal elateroids of doubtful affinity. Recent cladistic studies have not really clarified the position of Callirhipidae. Costa \i{}et al.\i0{} (1999) considered both callirhipids and eulichadids to be \i{}incertae sedis\i0{} within Elateriformia, and Beutel (1995) found that Eulichadidae (combined with Ptilodactylidae excluding Araeopidiinae and Cladotominae) and Callirhipidae formed two basal clades at the base of a group consisting of most of the remaining elateriforms (taxa usually comprising the Dryopoidea, Elateroidea and Cantharoidea). The latter analysis was based only on larvae.>
<Males of some \i{}Ichthyurus\i0{} have the mesofemora greatly enlarged.>

<There seems to be little doubt that \i{}Cerophytum\i0{} belongs to the elateroid complex, sharing a similar clicking mechanism with those members of the group in which it has not been secondarily lost. The well-developed, movable (though concealed), prothoracic pleurotrochantin prompted Hlavac (1975) to include the genus in an redefined Artematopoidea; however in most cladistic analyses the taxon is either basal to the elateroids or sister to Throscidae (Lawrence 1988, Calder \i{}et al.\i0{} 1993, Beutel 1995, Muona 1995). The larva, described by Mamaev (1978) and Lawrence (1991), is highly unusual in having unique sucking mouthparts involving paired sucking grooves and styliform mandibles and maxillae, paired thoracic and abdominal glands and bifurcate pretarsi. \i{}Anischia\i0{}, sometimes included here, is placed in a separate family (See ANISCHIIDAE).>
<Galea bifurcate.>

<The genus \i{}Cneoglossa\i0{} is usually placed in Ptilodactylidae (or in an expanded Dascillidae), but Crowson (1972) considered it to form a family in Cantharoidea and Brown (1981) included it in a list of genera of Psephenidae. In cladograms based on both adults and larvae (Costa \i{}et al.\i0{} 1999), Cneoglossidae formed the sister group of Psephenidae and the two together were sister to Ptilodactylidae plus Chelonariidae.>
<\i{}Coptocera\i0{} Murray, 1868 (= \i{}Cinnabarium\i0{} Fairmaire, 1895).>

<On the basis of female characters only, Lawrence \i{}et al.\i0{} (1995) found that \i{}Declinia relicta\i0{} consistently clustered with members of the Scirtoidea. Descriptions and illustrations of male genitalia in the Japanese \i{}D. versicolor\i0{} (Sakai and Satô 1996) do not contradict a placement in that superfamily, but given the basal position of the entire group, larval characters could shed additional light on the origin of the Polyphaga.>

<Hinton (1937) illustrated the antenna of \i{}Ceradryops\i0{} and showed it to have 3 antennomeres; however a dissected specimen assumed to be the same species definitely has 5. The dissected specimen could be a different species, but Hinton had only a female in poor condition, and the number of antennomeres may vary in \i{}C. punctatus\i0{}.>
<This taxon has been coded from the literature only.>
<This ITEM is based primarily on the descriptions of Perkins and Spangler, and some characters were coded based on states used for DRYOPIDAE (major part).>

<Included genera: \i{}Adrastus\i0{}, \i{}Ctenoplus\i0{}, \i{}Glyphonyx\i0{}, \i{}Lanecarus\i0{}, \i{}Microglyphonyx\i0{}, \i{}Neosilesis\i0{}, \i{}Peripontius\i0{}, \i{}Silesis\i0{}, \i{}Synaptus\i0{} and \i{}Tolphorea\i0{}.>
<Included genera: \i{}Anchiszombatya\i0{}, \i{}Melanotus\i0{}, \i{}Metriaulacus\i0{}, \i{}Neofleutiauxia\i0{}, \i{}Priopus\i0{}, \i{}Psellis\i0{}, \i{}Szombatya\i0{}.>
<A deep pit laterad of the antennal insertion looks very similar to the "fosse cephalique" described by Coffin (1992) in Throscidae.>

<The Australian genera \i{}Antoligostethus\i0{}, \i{}Nullarborica\i0{} and \i{}Patriciella\i0{}, formerly included in this group, were removed by Calder (1996), who placed the first two in Elaterinae and the last in Cardiophorinae. It is possible that the remaining taxa do not form a monophyletic group.>

<Lampyrinae, as understood here, includes the Psilocladinae (= Cyphonocerinae), which was considered by Crowson (1972) to be a separate subfamily. Molecular studies based on several Japanese genera have shown that Psilocladinae and Lampyrinae form a clade, and it is difficult to find any morphological characters consistently separating the two, when the world fauna is taken into consideration.>

<This group is not well-defined, but probably includes many genera usually placed in Drilidae. Genera examined include: \i{}Ototreta\i0{} (= \i{}Drilaster\i0{}), \i{}Flabellotreta\i0{}, \i{}Stenocladius\i0{}, \i{}Brachylampis\i0{} and \i{}Lamellipalpodes\i0{}. Crowson (1972) also includes \i{}Harmatelia\i0{}, \i{}Mimophaeopterus\i0{}, \i{}Ceylonidrilus\i0{} and \i{}Picodrilus\i0{} in this subfamily. Suzuki (1997) reported that in a phylogenetic study based on molecular data \i{}Stenocladius\i0{} clustered with \i{}Rhagophthalmus\i0{} rather than with the ototretine genus \i{}Drilaster\i0{}. According to Ohba \i{}et al. (1997) and Kawashima (1999), \i{}Stenocladius\i0{} females are anelytrous with a larval head and adult legs bearing 2-segmented tarsi and paired claws. Due to lack of study material, these females are not coded in this matrix.>
<Kasap and Crowson (1975) included this genus in the family Chelonariidae.>
<Those Old World forms sometimes placed in this family by Crowson (1972) (e.g. \i{}Diplocladon\i0{}) are coded separately and placed in Rhagophthalmidae.>
<Those Old World forms sometimes placed in this family by Crowson (1972) (e.g. \i{}Diplocladon\i0{}) are coded separately and placed in Rhagophthalmidae.>
<Both maxillary lobes are highly reduced.>

<Although Lawrence and Newton (1995) placed this species at the end of the Elateriformia as \i{}Incertae Sedis\i0{}, Wittmer (1969), on the advice of R. A. Crowson, included it in Ptilodactylidae, and this is probably where the genus belongs. However, it would serve no purpose to merge this with a family, the monophyly of which is in doubt (Beutel 1995, Costa \i{}et al.\i0{} 1999).>
<The apical maxillary palpomere in some genera bears two processes and so appears to be bifurcate.>
<Both maxillary lobes reduced. Three distinct processes at apex of maxillary palp.>
<Galea bifurcate.>

<Except for the subfamily Ptilodactylinae and the genera \i{}Araeopidius\i0{}, \i{}Drupeus\i0{} and \i{}Octoglossa\i0{}, all Ptilodactylidae are included here. Some of these genera have been placed in the subfamilies Anchytarsinae, Aploglossinae and Cladotominae, but others remain unplaced within the family. Except for Stribling's unpublished thesis (1986) there has been no world revision of the group.>

<In addition to the widely distributed genus \i{}Ptilodactyla\i0{}, other genera belonging to this subfamily include \i{}Chelonariomorphus\i0{}, \i{}Lachnodactyla\i0{}, \i{}Pherocladus\i0{} and \i{}Stirophora\i0{}.>
<These beetles were placed in Phengodidae by Crowson (1972).>
<These beetles were placed in Phengodidae by Crowson (1972).>
<These beetles were placed in Phengodidae by Crowson (1972).>
<These beetles were placed in Phengodidae by Crowson (1972).>

<The head has a distinct median endocarina and the mandibles are perforate. The lobes on the tarsomeres are of an unusual type which are probably not homologous to those in Lissominae (Elateridae); there appear to be 3, not 2 on tarsomeres 1, 2 and 3, and 2 of the 3 are serrate.>

characters.name: mesepisterna <whether meeting at midline>

states: visible from above between pronotum and elytral base on each side
characters.name: mesepimeron <whether visible from above>
mesocoxal cavities <whether partly closed by metepisterna>

states: absent or not extending to middle of mesocoxal cavity
extending at least to middle of mesocoxal cavity
characters.name: mesoventral process <presence and extent>

states: a posteriorly curved, angulate or acute line
an anteriorly curved, angulate or acute line
characters.name: mesometaventral junction <presence and shape>

states: separated by gap, groove, or suture
solidly fused or separated at most by weakly impressed line
characters.name: mesoventral and metaventral processes at midline <whether fused>

states: formed by mesoventral tongue and coxal groove
formed by metaventral tongue and coxal groove
formed by coxal knob and mesoventral cavity
characters.name: accessory (mesal) mesocoxal articulation <type>

states: short <less than 0.25 X body of metaventrite>
characters.name: metaventral discrimen or median line <presence and extent>
paired postcoxal lines of metaventrite <whether present>

states: arched but not or slightly recurved
characters.name: postcoxal lines of metaventrite <type>

states: not longer than first abdominal ventrite
characters.name: metaventrite <whether shorter than first abdominal ventrite>

states: without transverse carina between mesocoxal cavities
with transverse ridge or carina joining posterior edges of mesocoxal cavities
characters.name: anterior edge of metaventrite <whether with transverse carina>

states: short and broad <less than 2.5 X as L as W>
moderately elongate <2.5-4 X as L as W>
very long and narrow or absent <more than 4 X as L as W>
characters.name: exposed portion of metepisternum <shape>

states: widely separated <at least 0.5 X longest coxal diameter>
characters.name: metacoxae <whether widely separated>

states: separated by less than longest coxal diameter
separated by more than 1 but less than 2 times longest coxal diameter
separated by more than 2 times longest coxal diameter
characters.name: metacoxae <whether separated by 1 or 2 times longest coxal diameter>

states: not extending laterally to meet elytra or sides of body
extending laterally to meet elytra or sides of body
characters.name: metacoxae <whether extending laterally to meet elytra or sides of body>

states: completely separated from metaventrite by suture
at least partly fused to metaventrite, suture incomplete or absent
characters.name: metacoxae <whether partly or completely fused to metaventrite>

states: well developed, more or less uniform
characters.name: metacoxal plates <degree of development>

states: not concealing most of basal abdominal ventrite
concealing most of first abdominal ventrite
concealing most of first three abdominal ventrites
characters.name: metacoxal plates <whether concealing basal abdominal ventrites>
lateral arms of metendosternite <whether moderately to very long>
ventrolateral processes of metendosternite <whether strongly developed>
anterior process of metendosternite <whether short or absent>

states: widely separated but not on lateral arms
on lateral arms or not apparent
characters.name: anterior tendons of metendosternite <whether widely separated or on arms>
apical portion of metendosternite <whether deeply emarginate>
hind wing <whether highly reduced or absent>
radial cell of hind wing <whether highly reduced or absent>
inner posterior angle formed at base of radial cell <whether acute>
ratio of length of apical area to total wing length

states: with one or more vague sclerotizations or pigment patches
with one or more distinct veins (branches of RA and-or RP)
characters.name: apical area of hind wing <whether with veins or sclerotizations>
medial bar of hind wing <whether crossed by fold>
free veins in medial area of hind wing <number>
oblongum cell of hind wing <whether absent>
medial fleck of hind wing <whether present>

states: absent or not partly bisected by a vein
characters.name: medial fleck of hind wing <whether partly bisected by a vein>
wedge cell of hind wing <whether reduced or absent>
apex of wedge cell of hind wing <shape>
anal lobe of hind wing <whether present>
posterior edge of hind wing <whether with fringe of long hairs>

states: strongly oblique with base of femur separate from coxa
strongly oblique with base of femur abutting coxa
characters.name: femoral attachment of mid trochanter <whether transverse or oblique>

states: not reduced or concealed from below
highly reduced, strongly oblique and concealed from below
characters.name: mesotrochanter <whether reduced and concealed or absent>

states: strongly widened, widest at or near apex
strongly widened, widest well before apex
characters.name: mesotibia <whether strongly widened>

states: with distinct teeth or long spines
characters.name: outer edge of mesotibia <whether spinose>
outer subapical edge of mesotibia <whether with antenna cleaner>

states: with transverse or oblique ridges or combs
characters.name: preapical surfaces of mesotibia <whether with ridges or combs>

states: simple or slightly produced, without lobe, teeth or spines
with one or more straight or outwardly facing teeth or spines
with rounded lobe or process, sometimes bearing spines
with inwardly curved or hooked spine (uncus)
characters.name: outer apical angle of mesotibia <armature>

states: not or slightly produced, without tooth
characters.name: inner apical angle of mesotibia <whether forming tooth>
mesotibial spurs <whether pubescent, serrate or pectinate>

states: with 4 distinct tarsomeres and reduced penultimate one (pseudotetramerous)
with 3 distinct tarsomeres and reduced penultimate one (pseudotrimerous)
characters.name: mesotarsus <number of distinct and reduced tarsomeres>

states: at least as many as on mid leg
characters.name: tarsomeres on hind leg <whether 1 fewer than on mid leg>

states: at least as many as on mid leg
characters.name: tarsomeres on fore leg <whether 1 fewer than on mid leg>
preapical mesotarsomeres together <whether shorter than apical one>
ventral mesotarsal lobes <presence, location and number>

states: subequal in length and similar in form and angle of inclination
characters.name: mesotarsal claws <whether differing in length, form or angle of inclination>

states: membranous or lightly sclerotized, usually pubescent
characters.name: appendage on each tarsal claw <type>

states: with one or more setae near base
characters.name: mesotarsal claws <whether with setae near base>

states: absent or with 2 or fewer setae
characters.name: mesotarsal empodium <whether with 3 or more setae>

states: simple and rounded to carinate but without lobes or teeth, except at apex
with one or more distinct lobes or teeth
characters.name: outer edge of protibia <whether with distinct lobes or teeth>

states: simple or slightly produced, without lobe, teeth or spines
with one or more straight or outwardly facing teeth or spines
with rounded lobe or process, sometimes bearing spines
with inwardly curved or hooked spine (uncus)
characters.name: outer apical angle of protibia <armature>
inner subapical edge of protibia <whether with antenna cleaner>

states: located in different planes, one being subapical
characters.name: articulations of protibial spurs <whether located in different planes>

states: with transverse or oblique ridges or combs
characters.name: preapical surfaces of metatibia <whether with ridges or combs>

states: not to only moderately expanded, narrowly oval or oblique
greatly expanded, broadly oval to circular and flattened
characters.name: metatibial articular area <whether broadly expanded and flattened>
metatibial spurs <whether differing in length and-or form>

states: present as concealed or partly exposed lateral sclerites
characters.name: abdominal sternite 2 <whether concealed or apparently absent>

states: divided into 2 or 3 parts by metacoxae
characters.name: first ventrite <whether completely divided by metacoxae>
suture between ventrites 1 and 2 <whether incomplete or vaguely indicated>
suture between ventrites 2 and 3 <whether incomplete or vaguely indicated>

states: articulated with or connate with both 3 and 5
characters.name: ventrite 4 <whether articulated with 3 but connate with 5>
postcoxal lines on ventrite 1 <presence and type>

states: about as long as or longer than ventrite 2
characters.name: ventrite 1 at middle of metacoxa <whether much shorter than 2>
ventrite 5 in female <whether with circular depression>
last visible tergite and-or sternite (7 or 8) <whether forming terminal spine>

states: separated by membrane or distinct suture
solidly fused, without or with incomplete suture between them
characters.name: tergite and sternite 7 <whether fused>
ventrites <whether with setose patches or foveae>
functional spiracles on abdominal segment 8 <whether absent>
functional spiracles on abdominal segment 7 <whether absent>
functional spiracles on abdominal segment 6 <whether absent>
functional spiracles on abdominal segment 5 <whether absent>

states: located on tergosternal suture or area of fusion
characters.name: 7th abdominal spiracles <position>
anterior edge of sternite 8 in male <whether with median strut>
anterior edge of sternite 9 in male <whether with median strut>

states: almost completely divided into two parts
characters.name: tergite 9 in male <whether emarginate or divided>

states: completely membranous or fused to tergite 9
characters.name: tergite 10 in male <whether fused to 9>

states: with single strut and opposing paired struts
characters.name: anterior edge of tegmen or phallobase <whether with strut(s)>
apicale or apical portion of tegmen <whether with accessory lobes>

states: individually articulated to phallobase or base of penis
fused to phallobase or base of penis but free from one another
partly or entirely fused together but articulated to phallobase
partly or entirely fused together and to phallobase, or absent
characters.name: parameres <whether fused to phallobase, fused together or absent>
penis <whether with dorsal and ventral lobes>
anterior edge of penis <whether with strut(s)>
